Additional Information Careers   FAQ   Alumni Profiles   Links and Resources                  Request More Information    Apply to Wagner                                      Ranked #8 in Health Policy and Management by U.S. News and World Report     NYU Wagner's Health Policy and Management program has been recognized as one of the best in the country. Located in a school of public service rather than in a medical or public health school, our program crosses traditional boundaries, linking management, finance, policy, and providing students with the cutting-edge concepts and skills needed to shape the future of health policy and management.   Students receive a set of tools and experiences that allow them to understand both the delivery of health care services and the broader social, cultural, and economic factors that influence health outcomes. Our students experience firsthand the importance of health care delivery and health promotion in one of the most interesting, diverse, and complex cities in the world, and our graduates work in every sector of the health care system.   Exploring ... WAGTalk: John Billings, “Improving Care for High Cost/ High Risk Patients”      Health      .                Ellen Schall, Martin Cherkasky Professor of Health Policy & Management      Health      .                                   Wagner's health program integrates policy and management across not-for-profit, community, and government fields, which is ideal for students whose careers are likely to transcend single sectors.   -Professor Anthony Kovner, Professor of Public and Health Management.       Related Links     MPA-Health Brochure   Advisement   Course Registration   Capstone   Student Journey   Study and Collaboration Spaces   Student Organizations   Wagner Health Network (WHN)   Wagner Management & Leadership Organization (WMLO)   Wagner Policy Alliance (WPA)                          Global Perspective   The international curriculum in NYU Wagner's Health Policy and Management teaches across disciplines and provides a deep understanding of the factors that impact health across the globe. Read More   The Health Policy and Management program provides a comparative interdisciplinary foundation that bridges cutting-edge conceptual thinking, critical analytical techniques and concrete health management skills. Students study the key factors that explain the unequal distribution of health and disease in the world, particularly in developing countries, and the modes of intervention to improve global health. Microeconomics for Public Management, Planning, and Policy Analysis | NYU Wagner                                    Jump to navigation                                                             Microeconomics for Public Management, Planning, and Policy Analysis   CORE-GP.1018, 3 points.       Courses         Description |    Syllabi |    Evaluations           The primary purpose of the microeconomics core course is to enable you to use microeconomic thinking, concepts and tools in your professional public service work. Accomplishing this also requires refreshing and strengthening your quantitative skills.      The course begins with the basics of supply and demand and market operations, and uses this as the context for considering consumer and organizational decisions within a given market structure. The course builds to applying economic analysis to a variety of public issues such as the effects of taxation, the market structure of health care, the impacts of the minimum wage, the effects of international trade and various approaches to environmental externalities.      By the end of the course you should be able to articulate the economic context and analysis of a public problem, use economic concepts in managerial and policy decisions, and progress to second level courses confident of your understanding of microeconomics and its tools.    Prerequisites: None                     Semester     Instructor     Syllabus Link         Spring 2015 Sewin Chan, Diana Beck Syllabus  Fall 2014 Erico Hoyt Dixon Syllabus  Fall 2014 Michael Suher Syllabus  Fall 2014 Jorge De la Roca Syllabus  Fall 2014 Ingrid Gould Ellen Syllabus  Spring 2014 Sewin Chan, Diana Beck Syllabus  Fall 2013 Sewin Chan, Diana Beck, Ingrid Gould Ellen Syllabus  Summer 2013 Jorge De la Roca Syllabus  Spring 2013 Sewin Chan Syllabus  Spring 2013 Sewin Chan Syllabus  Fall 2012 Ingrid Gould Ellen Syllabus  Fall 2012 Diana Beck Syllabus  Fall 2012 Diana Beck Syllabus  Fall 2012 Katherine M. The course builds to applying economic analysis to a variety of public issues such as the effects of taxation, the market structure of health care, the impacts of the minimum wage, the effects of international trade and various approaches to environmental externalities.      By the end of the course you should be able to articulate the economic context and analysis of a public problem, use economic concepts in managerial and policy decisions, and progress to second level courses confident of your understanding of microeconomics and its tools.    Prerequisites: None                     Semester     Instructor     Syllabus Link         Spring 2015 Sewin Chan, Diana Beck Syllabus  Fall 2014 Erico Hoyt Dixon Syllabus  Fall 2014 Michael Suher Syllabus  Fall 2014 Jorge De la Roca Syllabus  Fall 2014 Ingrid Gould Ellen Syllabus  Spring 2014 Sewin Chan, Diana Beck Syllabus  Fall 2013 Sewin Chan, Diana Beck, Ingrid Gould Ellen Syllabus  Summer 2013 Jorge De la Roca Syllabus  Spring 2013 Sewin Chan Syllabus  Spring 2013 Sewin Chan Syllabus  Fall 2012 Ingrid Gould Ellen Syllabus  Fall 2012 Diana Beck Syllabus  Fall 2012 Diana Beck Syllabus  Fall 2012 Katherine M.
